origination.corpname: Louis Sands Salt and Lumber Company (Manistee, Mich.)

did.unittitle: Louis Sands Salt and Lumber Company (Manistee, Mich.) records 1863-1932
did.abstract: Manistee, Michigan business firm; financial records, letterpress books, time books, and other records detailing to various business activities.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The record group was the gift of Mrs. Lottie B. Smith (donor no. 2335) and came to the library in September 1947.

accessrestrict.p: The record group is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Louis Sands Salt and Lumber Company (Manistee, Mich.) records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The Sands Salt and Lumber Company was one of the largest lumbering concerns in Manistee, Michigan. The firm was founded by Louis Sands, a Swede who was born on July 2, 1826,and who immigrated to the United States as a young man. After spending time in Boston and Chicago, Sands came to Manistee around 1853.

Between 1853 and 1856, Sands worked as a lumberjack. In 1856, he engaged in his first entrepreneurial venture, signing a contract to log another man's property. By 1864, Sands had saved enough money to buy an interest in a saw mill, and in 1870 he purchased for himself a small saw mill located in Eastlake.

Sands business prospered. In 1878, he became the owner of the bankrupt Tyron, Sweet & Co. Saw Mill, then the largest in the city. Located at the head of the Manistee River, it was equipped with the finest machinery available. In 1879, Sands sold the Eastlake Mill to R.G. Peters, and concentrated his energy on the former Tyron mill.

Sands continually expanded the base of his business operations. In 1889, he made a major purchase of timber land from the Grand Rapids and Indiana Railroad; and to exploit it he built both a harrow gauge railroad and a saw mill at Lake City. After removing more than 100,000,000 board feet from the area, Sands moved both railroad and mill to a new location, the former site of the Reitz mill on Manistee Lake. The Reitz operation Sands established was large, including the saw mill, a cooper shop, a machine shop, and two salt mills.

Sands was also involved with a variety of other business activities. Some of these, such as salt production and the operation of several ships, were closely associated with Sands lumbering operations. Others, such as the founding of Manistee's first electric power plant and a partnership in the banking firm of Sands & Burr, were less directly related to his primary concern of lumbering.
Louis Sands died August 24,1905, yet the company which he founded continued in existence for many years after his death.

scopecontent.p: The records of Louis Sands business interests have been arranged in seven series. These include letterpress books, journals, ledgers, time books, subsidiary volumes, associated records, and miscellaneous. The letterpress books and miscellaneous documents have been retained in their original format. The remaining material has been microfilmed.

The original relationship between much of the business records has been lost beyond reconstruction. Because of this, volumes have been grouped by type rather than by business venture. The loss of the original relationship between the volumes was responsible, as well, for the establishment of an arbitrary chronological order for some volumes.

All of the material microfilmed as well as a large quantity of material relating to Sands & Burr, bankers, which was not filmed, has been placed on permanent loan to the Manistee Historical Museum in Manistee.

controlaccess.corpname: Louis Sands Salt and Lumber Company (Manistee, Mich.)

scopecontent.p: There are two subseries of letterpress books. One, created through Sands banking activities, covers the years 1901-1929. The other subseries, correspondence of George M. Burr, trustee, is dated between 1902 and 1925. Both sets of letterpress books lack several volumes for the earliest years.
Most of the journals are from the Reitz plant, or its predecessor operations. A few journals, the purpose of which are unclear, have been arranged in chronological order.

Of the major record series, the ledgers are by far the most difficult to use. They have been divided into three groups, arbitrarily labeled 1, 2, and 3. The ledgers in groups 1 and 2 appear to be related to one another, but there is no indication as to what operations they were maintained for. Group 3 is a totally arbitrary arrangement of ledgers that did not appear to fit into either of the first two groups.

Like the journals, the source of most of the time books is identifiable. Of the two sets of time books, one comes from the "Third Ward Plant", and the other from the "Fourth Ward Plant". Sands' time books are of particular interest because his firm was a major employer of immigrant Swedes.

Subsidiary volumes contain record books which were related to a particular aspect of Sands business ventures, but which do not seem to be basic records of the firm. Among these volumes are the camp and mill scales records, the sales and purchases books, the salt production records and finally an inventory done for the receiver of the Louis Sands estate on March 20, 1925.

did.unittitle: Inventory for Receiver of Louis Sands March 20, 1925

scopecontent.p: Associated records include volumes of firms which were independent of Sands but which somehow became interspersed with the Sands records. It is possible Sands held either a minor interest in these firms, purchased the assets of the firm and integrated it into his 6perations, or was greatly interested in the work of the firm. Such records tend to be fragmentary. Included are the Manistee River Improvement Co.; Sands and Rothschild; W.A. Waite, Filer, Tyson, & Co.; Wadsworth, Adams & Co. Engelmann, Babcock & Salling; and the Boom Co. of Manistee.

odd.p: (target in error; volume re-shot on reel 30)
